case_name: Vadilal Panchal v. Dattatraya Dulaji Ghadigaonkar

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Petition Application No. 834 of 1957, arising out of the judgment and order dated April 30, 1957, of the Presidency Magistrate, IV Class, Girgaon, Bombay, in Case No. 6/1 R of 1956.

Sitaram died of the gunshot wound caused by a bullet fired by the appellant under such circumstances as would render the firing to be in exercise of the right of private defence and as such justified . This verdict was returned on October 16, 1956.

concepts.interpretation: Firing justified if in exercise of right of private defence, as found by Coroner's Jury, police, and Magistrate based on witness statements and circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then moved this Court and obtained special leave to appeal from the order of the High Court dated September 13,1957.

issues.text: Was the High Court right in its view that when a Magistrate directs an enquiry under s. 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for ascertaining the truth or falsehood of a complaint and receives a report from the enquiring officer supporting a plea of self-defence made by the person complained against, it is not open to him to hold that the plea is correct on the basis of the report and the statements of witnesses recorded by the enquiring officer? Must he, as a matter of law, issue process in such a case and leave the person complained against to establish his plea of self-defence at the trial?

anchor.surface_text: The short question before us isâ€”was the High Court right in its view that when a Magistrate directs an enquiry under s. 202 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for ascertaining the truth or falsehood of a complaint and receives a report from the enquiring officer supporting a plea of self-defence made by the person complained against, it is not open to him to hold that the plea is correct on the basis of the report and the statements of witnesses recorded by the enquiring officer ?

issues.text: Whether it would be correct to lay down a proposition in absolute terms that whenever a defence under any of the exceptions in the Indian Penal Code is pleaded by the person complained against, the Magistrate would not be justified in dismissing the complaint and must issue process

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out here that the High Court itself recognised that it would not be correct to lay down a proposition in absolute terms that whenever a defence under any of the exceptions in the Indian Penal Code is pleaded by the person complained against, the Magistrate would not be justified in dismissing the complaint and must issue process.

issues.text: Whether there is anything in s. 202 or s. 203 of the Criminal Procedure Code which abrogates the rule as to the presumption laid down in s. 105 of the Evidence Act and the mode of proof of exception laid down in that section

anchor.surface_text: We do not find anything in any of the sections in Chapter XVI to show that such an exception can be held to be established from the mere report of the police. That, in our view, is contrary to the provisions of s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act which are mandatory provisions. There is nothing in s. 202 or s. 203 of the Criminal Procedure Code which abrogates the rule as to the presumption laid down in s. 105 of the Evidence Act

issues.text: Whether the Magistrate can apply his judicial mind to the materials on record, including the result of s.202 inquiry, to consider a plea based on an exception like right of private defence and dismiss the complaint under s.203 if there is no sufficient ground for proceeding

anchor.surface_text: if after considering those materials there is in his judgment no sufficient ground for proceeding, he may dismiss the complaint. Section 204 says that if in the opinion of the Magistrate there is sufficient ground for proceeding, he shall take steps for the issue of necessary process. Now, in the case before us it is not contended that the learned Presidency Magistrate failed to consider the materials which he had to consider, before passing his order under s. 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

issues.text: Whether on the materials before the Magistrate, including witness statements and police inquiry report, there was sufficient ground for proceeding further on the complaint

anchor.surface_text: Section 204 says that if in the opinion of the Magistrate there is sufficient ground for proceeding, he shall take steps for the issue of necessary process. ... We cannot therefore say that the learned Magistrate was wrong in his judgment that there was no sufficient ground for proceeding further on the complaint.

That, in our view, is companytrary to the provisions of s. 105 of the Indian Evidence Act which are mandatory provisions.

holdings.text: We are of the view that the High Court was in error in holding in this case that as a matter of law, it was not open to the learned Presidency Magistrate to come to the conclusion that on the materials before him no offence had been made out and there was no sufficient ground for proceeding further on the complaint.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the view that the High Court was in error in holding in this case that as a matter of law, it was not open to the learned Presidency Magistrate to come to the conclusion that on the materials before him no

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court wrongly held Magistrate legally barred from accepting self-defence plea; ss.200-204 CrPC permit judicial assessment of all materials including defence at pre-process stage.

holdings.text: it would not be correct to lay down a proposition in absolute terms that whenever a defence under any of the exceptions in the Indian Penal Code is pleaded by the person complained against, the Magistrate would not be justified in dismissing the complaint and must issue process.

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out here that the High Court itself recognised that it would not be correct to lay down a proposition in absolute terms that whenever a defence under any of the exceptions in the Indian Penal Code is p

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court itself recognised no absolute rule; dismissal possible if complaint discloses complete defence or materials show no sufficient ground.

holdings.text: The Magistrate must apply his judicial mind to the materials on which he has to form his judgment. In arriving at his judgment he is not fettered in any way except by judicial considerations he is not bound to accept what the inquiring officer says, nor is he precluded from accepting a plea based on an exception, provided always there are satisfactory and reliable materials on which he can base his judgment as to whether there is sufficient ground for proceeding on the complaint or not.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate must apply his judicial mind to the materials on which he has to form his judgment. In arriving at his judgment he is not fettered in any way except by judicial considerations he is not bound to accept

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of s.203 requires judgment on complainant's statements, witnesses, s.202 result; no bar to defence pleas if reliable materials; scope of s.202 limited to truth/falsehood of complaint.

holdings.text: If the Magistrate has not misdirected himself as to the scope of an enquiry under s. 202 and has applied his mind judicially to the materials before him, we think that it would be erroneous in law to hold that a plea based on an exception can never be accepted by him in arriving at his judgment.

anchor.surface_text: If the Magistrate has not misdirected himself as to the scope of an enquiry under s. 202 and has applied his mind judicially to the materials before him, we think that it would be erroneous in law to hold that a p

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.105 Evidence Act mandatory but not abrogated by CrPC; Magistrate can judicially assess without full proof at trial stage.

holdings.text: We do not think that any of the aforesaid decisions lays down any such proposition in absolute terms as is contended for on behalf of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: We do not think that any of the aforesaid decisions lays down any such proposition in absolute terms as is contended for on behalf of the respondent. In Emperor v. Dhondu Bapu  1  a complaint charging defama

holdings.text: We cannot therefore say that the learned Magistrate was wrong in his judgment that there was no sufficient ground for proceeding further on the complaint.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overwhelming materials (police reports, witness statements, inconsistencies, Coroner's jury) support private defence; complainant witnesses unworthy of credence.

holdings.text: We accordingly hold that the High Court set aside the order of the learned Magistrate on an erroneous view of the scope of s. 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly hold that the High Court set aside the order of the learned Magistrate on an erroneous view of the scope of s. 203 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: erroneous legal view on s.203 scope leads to improper reversal; Magistrate's order restored.
